page.title: 02Landscape in Southwick
page.content: The area is generally devoted to farming and woodland. The tributaries of the westerly flowing Wallington river crosses the area. In the far South East is situated{H.M.S.Dryad}and {Southwick House,}both inaccessible to the public. The woodland which covers about a quarter of the area is scattered randomly among the farmland. It is situated mainly in the north and is particularly dense. The areas are mainly mixed with both deciduous and coniferous trees,including oak, ash, beech and hazel trees. Coniferous woodland occurs less frequently than the mixed, and covers smaller areas like Friar's Coppice. Trees like spruce and silver birch are frequent and in Staple Cross Copse in Boarhunt some of the woodland is used commercially.
